There are two alarming factors shielded from the general public and in exercises like the link. Debt service on the national debt, which has passed $7 trillion, is allocated into the various government agencies and departments where the debt was originally incurred. While it's easy to arbitrarily increase defense by say 3% for public consumption, the majority of our national debt (80%) was incurred by and supposedly allocated to the DoD. For 2005, the DoD budget (this includes various departments such as nuclear arms maintenance and others budgeted elsewhere for public consumption and money for Iraq to be funded after the 2004 elections) is:
 
 Current military - $536 billion
 Iraq/Afghanistan - 50 billion (ha ha ha)
 Past military - 349 billion
 
 Of the past military expenses, veteran's benefits are $69 billion while interest on the national debt is $180 billion. Funny accounting? We'll pay almost $400 billion in interest on the national debt in 2005, yet less than 50% will be allocated to DoD in 2005, who incurs 80% of the debt. Ah, politics. Allocate the interest elsewhere, reduce the actual dollars available for other domestic services, say you're only increasing defense by a small amount and have even more to spend while pushing domestic services expenses down to the state level. We business people would go immediately to jail for such practices. Calculate the percentage of debt service to budget and see how long your business would last. 
 
 The other, more dangerous factor is the seemingly bottomless contingency fund. Budgets don't mean much anymore when any president can spend what he wants from contingency funds, which never make the public budget except as debt service the following year. And having the ability to pressure congress into quietly raising the national debt level as required is real kid in a candy store mentality. 
 
 Elections don't change these practices, regardless of which party is in office, and you won't see them in election campaigns. Special interests and personal greed manage our country, the public's elected representatives are merely the enablers in for their shares.
